timeline.title: Our Journey
timeline.subtitle: From a student forum to a worldwide open-source education platform

2019.title: EnterMedSchool is Born
2019.description: Ari Horesh creates EnterMedSchool as a forum for IMAT exam students to help each other study and share resources.

2020.title: Free Content Begins
2020.description: Ari starts releasing free educational content, collaborating with OpenStax materials to provide quality open-source study resources.

2021.title: Leading IMAT Course
2021.description: Launch of paid IMAT courses, becoming the world's leading IMAT preparation course for international students. Revenue funds the creation of free resources.

2025.title: New Generation
2025.description: Expanding to medical students, connecting with professors and doctors worldwide to verify and create content, releasing everything for free.

2026.title: Open Source Goes Official
2026.description: Launch of EnterMedSchool.org, Anki addon, Chrome extension, and a wave of open-source resources. The goal of EnterMedSchool was always to fund this project — and we finally did it.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.quote: We believe knowledge and tools to improve the quality of teaching should be open source.
mission.description: EnterMedSchool focuses on deep clinical understanding, not memorization. We provide professors and students with the tools to visualize what matters clinically, creating better doctors worldwide.
mission.relationship: EnterMedSchool.com funds this project through paid courses and services. Everything here on .org is free, open-source, and always will be. This is the archive — download, adapt, and use anything you find for your classroom.

cta.title: Download, Embed, or Adapt for Your Classroom
cta.subtitle: Every resource on EnterMedSchool.org is free and open-source. Use them in your slides, teaching materials, or share with your students.

about.title: About EnterMedSchool
about.metaDescription: Learn about the story of EnterMedSchool, from a student forum to a worldwide open-source medical education platform.

story.title: Our Story
story.content: EnterMedSchool was created in 2019 by Ari Horesh as a simple forum where IMAT exam students could help each other. What started as a community project grew into the world's leading IMAT preparation platform, and now, an open-source medical education resource for the world.

orgMission.title: Why .org?
orgMission.content: The goal of EnterMedSchool.com was always to fund this project. The paid courses and services on our main site enable us to create and maintain free, open-source educational tools for students and professors worldwide. EnterMedSchool.org is where that mission lives.

values.title: What We Believe
values.openSourceDesc: All our resources are free to use for non-commercial educational purposes.
values.understandingDesc: Our content focuses on deep clinical understanding, not rote memorization.
values.worldwideDesc: Quality medical education resources should be accessible to everyone, everywhere.
values.collaborationDesc: We work with professors and doctors worldwide to verify and create content.

bmi.title: BMI Calculator
bmi.metaTitle: BMI Calculator — Free Online Body Mass Index Tool | EnterMedSchool
bmi.metaDescription: Calculate your Body Mass Index (BMI) with clinical interpretation, BMI Prime, Ponderal Index, and WHO risk categories. Free, open-source, and embeddable.
bmi.description: Calculate Body Mass Index with clinical interpretation, risk assessment, and WHO classification.

labels.bmiPrimeDesc: Ratio of your BMI to the upper limit of normal (25). Values below 1.0 are within the healthy range.
labels.ponderalIndexDesc: A measure that adjusts for height better than BMI. Normal range: 11–15 kg/m³.
labels.waistGuidanceDesc: BMI alone does not capture abdominal fat distribution. Measure your waist circumference for a more complete risk picture.
labels.waistMaleRisk: Men: Increased risk above 94 cm (37 in) — High risk above 102 cm (40 in)
labels.waistFemaleRisk: Women: Increased risk above 80 cm (31.5 in) — High risk above 88 cm (34.6 in)
labels.ageContextDesc: BMI thresholds are designed for adults aged 20+. Interpretation may vary with age, sex, muscle mass, and ethnicity.
labels.ageContextUnder20: For individuals under 20, BMI is interpreted using age- and sex-specific percentile charts (CDC or WHO). The standard adult BMI categories shown above may not apply.
labels.healthyRange: For your height, a healthy weight (BMI 18.5–25) is {min}–{max} {unit}.
labels.scaleAlt: BMI color scale ranging from underweight through normal to obese categories
labels.validationAge: Age must be between 2 and 120 years.
labels.disclaimer: This calculator is for educational purposes only. It is not a substitute for professional medical judgment. Always consult a healthcare professional for clinical decisions.
labels.weightAbove: You are {value} {unit} above the upper end of the healthy range.
labels.weightBelow: You are {value} {unit} below the lower end of the healthy range.
labels.weightWithin: Your weight is within the healthy range.
labels.emptyStateDesc: Results will appear here automatically as you type.

faq.a1: Body Mass Index (BMI) is a numerical value calculated from a person's weight and height. It is used as a screening tool to categorize individuals into weight status categories such as underweight, normal weight, overweight, and obese. The World Health Organization (WHO) uses BMI as a standard measure for population-level health assessments.
faq.a2: BMI is calculated by dividing a person's weight in kilograms by their height in meters squared (kg/m²). For example, a person weighing 70 kg with a height of 1.75 m would have a BMI of 70 / (1.75 × 1.75) = 22.9. In imperial units, you can multiply weight in pounds by 703 and divide by height in inches squared.
faq.q3: What is a healthy BMI range?
faq.a3: According to the WHO, a healthy BMI for adults is between 18.5 and 24.9 kg/m². A BMI below 18.5 is classified as underweight, 25.0 to 29.9 as overweight, and 30.0 or above as obese. These thresholds are designed for adults aged 20 and older; children and adolescents use age- and sex-specific percentile charts.
faq.q4: What are the limitations of BMI?
faq.a4: BMI does not distinguish between muscle mass, bone density, and fat mass. Athletes or muscular individuals may have a high BMI despite having low body fat. BMI also does not account for fat distribution — abdominal fat carries higher health risks than fat stored in other areas. Ethnicity, age, and sex can also influence the relationship between BMI and health risk.
faq.a5: BMI Prime is the ratio of a person's BMI to the upper limit of the healthy range (BMI 25). A BMI Prime of 1.0 means you are at the upper boundary of normal weight. Values below 1.0 indicate you are within or below the healthy range, while values above 1.0 indicate overweight or obesity. It provides a quick, intuitive way to see how far from the healthy threshold you are.

education.aboutBody: Body Mass Index (BMI) is one of the most widely used measures in public health and clinical medicine. Developed by Belgian mathematician Adolphe Quetelet in the 1830s, BMI provides a simple numerical relationship between a person's weight and height. The World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and national health services worldwide use BMI to screen for weight categories that may lead to health problems. While it is not a diagnostic tool on its own, BMI serves as a useful starting point for identifying potential health risks related to body weight.
education.formulaBody: The BMI formula divides a person's body mass (in kilograms) by the square of their height (in meters). This produces a single number expressed in units of kg/m².
education.formulaExample: For example, a person who weighs 70 kg and is 1.75 m tall has a BMI of 70 / (1.75 × 1.75) = 22.9 kg/m², which falls within the normal weight category. In imperial units, the formula is: weight (lbs) × 703 / height (in)².
education.limitationsBody: While BMI is a convenient screening metric, it has well-documented limitations that clinicians and researchers recognize:
education.limitation1: BMI does not distinguish between lean muscle mass, bone density, and body fat. Athletes and muscular individuals may be classified as overweight or obese despite having low body fat percentages.
education.limitation2: BMI does not account for fat distribution. Visceral (abdominal) fat is strongly associated with cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, but BMI cannot measure where fat is stored in the body.
education.limitation3: The standard BMI thresholds were developed primarily from data on European populations. Research suggests that health risks associated with a given BMI may vary across different ethnic groups — for example, some Asian populations experience elevated risk at lower BMI values.
education.limitation4: BMI is designed for adults aged 20 and older. For children and adolescents, BMI is interpreted using age- and sex-specific percentile charts published by the WHO or CDC, as body composition changes significantly during growth and development.

philosophy.title: Collaboration Over Competition
philosophy.content: Medical school can sometimes push you to compete with your peers. We believe the best doctors are built through collaboration. We encourage students to help each other, share resources, and build healthy communities.
